meta_data.title: A Conversation with Dr. Jim Denison

I'm not a good slave master, not even to me. Anyway, that strikes me as a painful realization.
But I think it's encouraging even how Dr. Dennison was talking about, we're seeing this change in
culture already. Like we're seeing the realization that we do have rebel and no tools. And I think
that's encouraging. Because when you think about it, like even when it comes to, quote unquote,
building your own identity or defining your own identity with the rise of being aware of mental
health, I feel like people realize we're not, we're not dependable. Like every day, if I'm aware of
what's going on in myself, I don't even feel the same way about myself every day. And so with
things like that, I think that's encouraging to me because I think the realization of that is where
the rebuilding has to start. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. And one of the last things that he was saying,
it's something that I feel like weighs on a lot of people's mind, especially when they're thinking
about evangelism and sharing the truth of the gospel is like, okay, well, if we're living in
this post truth culture, right? What is, I mean, am I wasting my time sharing the truth of the gospel
or in like, and maybe that's the wrong verbiage, but it's like, am I just going to be met with a
lot of like, well, that's your truth kind of a thing. And, and then, then have to walk down that
even more difficult road. And I liked that he was saying, you know, when you, when you display the
relevance of your faith, then you're able to share the rightness of your faith. And just being like
the, I know we say it a lot in, in churchy language, but being the hands and feet of Jesus,
right? Being there when things are difficult and showing that, Hey, the Bible speaks to
caring for the marginalized and caring for the fatherless and caring for people who
are suffering and, and being, being in those situations, then can kind of lend itself to
people listening to you as well. Yeah. Very good. That was, that was a good, that was a helpful,
I hope it's helpful to our listeners out there to get to hear from Dr. Denison. And again,
lovely opportunity to get to connect to someone who offers insight value. I mean, obviously,
anyone who knows Jim, he's wicked smart. And, and another good example of someone who, who isn't
easy to just dismiss as, Oh, one of those. And so, yeah, I'd love to encourage people to,
to get engaged with, with the materials that he puts out on a regular basis.
I guess twice a day now, it sounds like, which is impressive. Hey, could we, hey,
Colson, could we start? Sure. Cranking up to twice a day. Just kidding. He said sure before he even
heard the question. And then he knew what was coming. He could tell over the look on my face.
What Chris is about to say isn't serious. He's calling my bluff. He's like, yeah, Chris, yeah,
you just take a couple hours a day. Can we get somebody else to do my expense report?
Do today.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. We'll help other people
find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at
info at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource of Southspring Baptist church.
Remember, don't give up, trust God, search for answers.
